criticalSuccess: You become one with the water, your body transformed into a vessel of pure aquatic efficiency. Each stroke is poetry in motion - arms slicing through the surface with barely a splash, legs driving you forward with metronomic precision. Your breathing is perfectly controlled, never breaking your rhythm. You don't fight the water - you use it, working with the current, reading the waves, finding the path of least resistance. The distance melts away beneath your mastery. You swim with the confidence and skill of someone for whom water is a second home!

Power and technique combine into swimming excellence. Your shoulders roll with each stroke, muscles flexing in perfect sequence to drive maximum force through the water. Your streamlined form cuts through the waves like a knife, leaving barely a ripple in your wake. This is athletic performance at its peak - beautiful, efficient, and devastatingly effective!
success: You swim with workmanlike efficiency, arms and legs moving in steady rhythm. It's not flashy, but it works. Stroke after stroke, you propel yourself forward, slowly but surely covering the distance you need to travel.

failure: The water seems to actively resist your efforts. Every stroke feels like you're pulling against syrup. Your legs kick with decreasing effectiveness. Your swimming degrades into floundering. Arms and legs churn the water frantically, expending tremendous energy but accomplishing nothing. You're not sinking, but you're also not going anywhere. It's exhausting and futile.
criticalFailure: In one terrible moment, everything goes wrong. Maybe it's a wave you didn't see, maybe it's sudden exhaustion, maybe it's panic - but the result is the same. Your swimming fails completely. Your head goes under water before you can draw breath. You try to fight your way back to the surface, but your limbs won't cooperate. Water floods your mouth as you sink. The surface gets farther away. Your lungs scream for air. Bubbles stream upward as you plunge downward. This is drowning, and it's happening now!

Your technique collapses catastrophically. One second you're swimming, the next you're sinking. Your arms thrash uselessly. Your legs cramp or simply stop working. Panic overrides training. You go under, the water closing over your head like a grave. You struggle desperately toward what you think is up, but you're disoriented, lungs burning, terror rising. The water has claimed you!
